ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 0 hrs on a normal week. Moderate preparation for midterm (~4 hrs), significant time on final paper.

This really depended on the week. The final project was pretty work-intensive, so the last couple of weeks were challenging. Earlier in the semester I only spent an hour or two on the course outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I am glad we have a course on this important and interesting topic, but it has a lot of room for improvement. The whole semester long course included only 7 lectures by the instructor plus one guest lecture. The professor states in the beginning of the course that because this is a graduate school class, the learning should be self motivated and she is just there to guide us with some lectures. I initially appreciated this attitude, but later realized that it is mostly an excuse not to put a lot of effort into teaching us. The midterm is an Epi study critique, a la Tong's assignments in Environmental Epi, and the final is a study grant proposal. These assignments are good Epi exercises, but do not require you to know anything about hormones. (I would even suggest that Epi be a pre-req for this course.)

This course was not my very best experience.I am more interested in reproductive health, and had much higher expectations for this field. Very little of this subject was a part of the course. Endocrine disruptors and birth defects was not even mentioned.

I think this course focuses on a very interesting topic, and the lectures were very clear and informative. The overall organization of the course was also excellent. My one suggestion would be that the course might be more interactive. For example, students could practice for the midterm and gain experience critiquing scientific articles by answering questions in class, in a discussion format. This might help break up the lecture portion of the course a bit, especially since it is almost 2 hours long.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Yawei Zhang  Yawei is very nice and does her best to be responsive to students in class. She does not hold office hours, but encourages students to make appointments to stop by. She is the type of professor who is clearly teaching only because she is required to but prefers and prioritizes her research.
Instructor: Yawei Zhang  Prof Zhang was always very welcoming to the students.The individual sessions were really useful.

Instructor: Yawei Zhang  The instructor of the course is extremely knowledgeable about this subject, and able to talk about her personal research efforts in addition to the work of others. Her lectures were well organized and very clear, though making more space for students to participate and practice articulating the issues and critiquing studies might be considered as potential ways of improving the course in the future.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course requires very little work. A good second-year second-semester course when you really need to be working on your thesis, not on your classes. If you are in the MPH program and know your Epi, this class is very easy. If you don't have any Epi background, then you will probably have to put more effort into it since all of the assignments are Epi based. If you really want to learn about environmental hormones, then prepare to be self-motivated and put the work in on your own time.
